text:
So, in Latin class the morning greeting was "salve!". And I now learn that is still a greeting in Italy these days.
How is it (is it) used in normal situations?

comments.comment_text:
It’s usually used as a greeting to someone you know but maybe not very well
More formal than ‘ciao’ x

I always use “Salve” in shops and restaurants, “ciao” is really informal, it’s okay to great a friend, but not with someone you don’t know, and buongiorno/
buonasera is way too formal
Salve I’ve told is a more proper greeting people who are not that close to you- Ciao is for casual informal..
Salve Regina

Salve is used when you can’t say ‘you’ to someone but you must use the formal ‘lei’ or ‘usted’ for those who know spanish. And that is used for people you either don’t know or you highly regard or simply you don’t have enough intimacy with like a friend or a colleague or family. If for example you enter a bar or a restaurant you don’t say ciao, you say salve or buongiorno.
Salve is the formal of hello. Ciao is the informal.
Cycling in Italy, we were frequently greeted by fellow cyclists with a hearty “Salve”.
Instead of Ciao...Salve Is less coloquial but yes, It Is still in use
How is it pronounced? Can someone write it phonetically please.
As an Italian learner,I use it to address someone more formally than ciao,but you can’t use salve as goodbye like ciao
I use it when I get into a place to greet strangers
English is very casual. Spanish in Mexico you have a formal way of greeting and speaking to someone say an adult or just introduce.

I’ve been thinking about this and looking for the Aussie equivalent
Buongiorno = good morning/ good day to you
Salve = hello
Ciao = hi or g’day
Does that sound right?

text:
I HOPE THIS HELPS SOMEONE!!!!

Quick story time: I was at the public beach in almafi when I was approached by a younger possibly Hispanic female. She asked if I spoke Spanish and I told her yes. First she asked if I could share “cell phone service” with her… first red flag. She explained that her brother was on the way to almafi and was coming via bus. She said￼ she didn’t have service so she just wanted to let him know that she would be waiting for him at the beach and their dad would be waiting for him at the bus stop. I must have looked confused so she went to her own phone and went into settings… I did the same. I asked her if she meant hotspot and she said no… she then proceeded to ask if she could use my phone to call her brother… Second red flag as now I was scared she would take my phone and take off running. I offered to send her brother a text instead, and she insisted it be through WhatsApp… she insisted she could type it herself, but at this point, I was starting to feel uncomfortable, so I just told her I would send it myself so I can get rid of her. The male had a germany phone number…. Another red flag!!!! She thanked me and left. I then received a phone call from a friend and began to chat with them. As I was still talking to my friend on the phone, I received a phone call from her supposed brother, but since I was already on the phone, I did not answer. As I looked around for the girl
She was, of course, nowhere in sight. The whole situation still never set right with me. The following morning when I woke up I was notified that my ‎WhatsApp account was flagged for spam, and it was permanently deleted. I can’t say for sure that text message was the culprit, but my gut feeling told me that it had something to do with it. The more I think about it my theory is that if I would’ve answered that guys phone call, he would’ve started asking me for money and gave me some Sob story about how he was stuck at the train station with no money and needed funds… I’m also thinking that that female had already been reported and that alleged Germany phone number was flagged thus my WhatsApp account was also flagged. I just wanted to share this quick story and remind everybody to stay vigilant and if something doesn’t feel right, go with your gut feeling and stay safe. ￼

comments.comment_text: I will not help anyone no matter what ! God job !
Thank you

Sorry this took time away from your vacation. I’ve learned the easiest thing to do is to just walk away from the beginning of this sort of situation. It sounds like this has taken too much time in your head. A real emergency can be handled by the authorities available.
Thank you for sharing.
Thank you for sharing and great to hear that your homework, common sense and instincts kicked in to prevent a miserable holiday
Tony Sirianni Adrian Sirianni Alyssa Sirianni Olivia Sirianni something else to look out for
Glad you trusted your gut.
Agreed. Glad you went with your gut instinct.
Thanks for sharing and also happy you trusted your own intuition

Robert Corpuz
Read this….
Well done 👏
So your what’s up account is closed??? Thanks for letting us know, if it happens to me, will just tell them to go to carabinieri office for help.

Good job!!!!!!

That’s a great reminder that ANYONE asking to touch/hold/
borrow your phone is SUSPICIOUS and should be redirected to government officials for help.

Also, per her story, if her dad was waiting at the bus station and she was waiting at beach then there really was no need for a panicked phone call. The brother would show up and figure it out either way. I would never have sent a WhatsApp message for a stranger.
Samara Zahra AmjadLaaibah Amjadread this
Your gut feeling is always a good thing to trust.

Tourist are targeted for scams- best to, while in foreign or unfamiliar areas, to ignore strange people - walk away from people or situations- where strangers approach you to selling or asking for help or giving help or to sign petitions.
Glad you dodged that bullet!

text: Where would be the best, most central and cheap place to stay as a base? We’re a couple with a car that want to visit Pompeii, Naples and the Amalfi coast before heading to Rome mid October. I was thinking Sorrento, Salerno or somewhere on the Amalfi coast. Also, would four or five days be enough? Thanks in advance. 😊

comments.comment_text: Sorrento! We did Pompeii, Capri, Positano and explored Sorrento in five days.
Sorrento is the best
Loved sorrento as a base last week 😊

Since you have a car, you have many options. Salerno is a better option for mobility by getting on A3 fast, easy drive to Pompeii Scavi. Much more reasonably priced lodging should be found there in Salerno. Salerno is the end of SS 163 Amalfi Coast drive. I do not recommend driving into Napoli, though. However, you can take a high speed train to Napoli Centrale and have fun for a day.
Also someone mentioned that ferry service to certain Amalfi destinations are available
We did 10 days in Sorrento as a home base - had a car and didn’t use it because public transportation is really easy around that region and parking and driving are not 😊

Definitely Sorrento - everything is close by. Train for Pompeii and Naples, bus from train station to Positano/
Amalfi or ferry to Amalfi and ferry to Capri.

Allow one place per day, so you have time to relax and enjoy your surroundings too. If you need a hotel recommendation,
I can highly recommend Hotel Plaza Sorrento - very reasonably priced, great staff and added bonus of rooftop bar and infinity pool. Also less than 1 min walk to Piazza Tasso and a 5 min walk from the train station.

Enjoy it all. I loved it there and I'm sure you will too.
Sorrento

There’s a Castle right in the port. A fabulous Shopping Mall. Do a great walking tour.
You can google ferry along the Sorrento Coast.
Just use google and find what interests you.

There are a lot of variables in your plan. If you are arriving from an international city, you will be required to go through customs in order to leave the airport. If you take a taxi to central Naples or a bus will make a difference between 5 minutes or 30 minutes in each direction. To get your next flight you are required to be at the airport 2 hours prior for domestic and 3 hours prior for international.

7 hour layover

1 hour disembark and customs (if international arrival)

15 minutes to storage luggage

5 (taxi) - 30 (bus) minutes from the airport to Central Naples

5 (taxi) - 30 (bus) minutes from Central Naples to the airport

2 or 3 hours advance arrival at the airport (domestic / international)

That leaves you 1 hour 45 minutes to 3 hours 30 minutes to sightsee depending on all the variables.

Hi, all. Planning a trip in October for my oldest who graduated college and has moved away. I have airline tickets booked and most hotels. I’m doing a mix of staying on points (thus the locations selected) and staying at boutique hotels. Here is our general itinerary:
Rome 1 night
Pisa or Grotta Giusti Resort (Tuscany) 3 nights
Sorrento 3 nights
Rome 1 night
Biggest thing keeping me from being able to finalize lodging and activities is transportation. One of our excursions starts in Florence but we want to be on our own the rest of the days there. We also want to check out Cinque Terre area so the car feels necessary.

We get in at 1300 to Rome after an overnight flight so our initial thought was to stay in Rome for one night then head up to Tuscany. But I’m wondering if that’s going to be a bigger pain than just heading up that same day.
Do we get the car in Rome and drive up or are we better off taking the train? If we rent a car, is the airport the only option for picking it up?
If we get a car for Tuscany can I drop it off there and take the train down to the coast? Or are we better off getting a flight from Florence to the coast?
Thanks in advance and apologies for the basic questions, but I haven’t been to Italy since I was seven. 😆

comments.comment_text: We stayed in Rome and explored by foot. Then got a car and drove to Tuscany (Siena & surrounding areas) and dropped it in Florence. Explored there by foot. Took train from Florence to Pisa (with 2 hr layover to walk to the tower) and then took train to Monterosso and stayed there. Can hike or take trains to other towns in Cinque Terre - super easy.

Regarding excursion, you can part the group and go on your own. You need to notify the group leader/tour operator at what point/
location you want to leave the tour. Returning to your lodging is your responsibility, by the way.
Rental car. Many rental car agencies are available in Roma throughout the city, especially at Roma Termini station. The most important thing is where you are going to drop off the car. Use Google Map and punch in your desired town of choice and see who has an office there. We usually take train to the furthest we can go before picking up our car. Last time we rented a car in Toscana, we picked up a car when leaving Firenze and returned it in Orvieto, then took a train to Roma.
Fatigue from a long flight should be taken in consideration. We are not a big fan of picking up a car at the airport especially immediately after long journey(we start from LA), so we take a train(rest time for us) as far as we can, then pick up a car if necessary. Italian railroad system is impressively well connected. Unless you are going to the countryside, it is more efficient to take advantage of the fabulous train system. For example, we took a high speed train from Firenze to Bologna and picked up a car there instead of driving from Firenze. I do understand that there are people who only want to drive a car to everywhere and avoid trains at all cost.
I hope that my experience helps.
In the end, you have to decide how you want to execute your plan.
Happy Planning!
Very good tips!! I will agree as native Roman and Italian

text: Italia Lago di Como
Hello what is the best shopping area in rome?

Hi everyone! We are going to Naples in late June 2024 and planning 1 day trip to Amalfi Coast or Procida. What should we choose?

About the day in Amalfi Coast, we hesitate between :
1. Sorrento (by train) + Amalfi by ferry
2. Vietri sul mare (by train) + Amalfi (by ferry)

comments.comment_text: 1 day isn’t enough. Ferry stops running fairly early. There’s so much to see! But if you do get to Amalfi, up the mountain (it’s quite a hike but totally worth it) is the Agricola Fore Porta a beautiful farm to table restaurant where everything is homemade. So wonderful!

They are both beautiful but I would choose the Amalfi Coast and visit the town of Amalfi. It is the largest town on the Coast and has much to offer.You can visit the Amalfi cathedral,go shopping and have lunch at one of the many restaurants that are in Amalfi.The last ferry to return does leave around 6pm. but at least you will get to see at least one town on the coast.
Ferries leave from the Molo Beverello port in Naples to Amalfi. You can always pre book online next year closer to your date. I recommend this as the Amalfi Coast is popular especially in the Spring and Summer months. This is a beautiful trip by water. Check ferry hopper online for schedules.You can take the train to Sorrento but will then have to take a bus to the towns on the Coast as the train does not run along the Coast.Will take longer to get there.
Another way of seeing it is to take a tour of the coast with a tour company if you choose to do that.You can get to Vietri sul Mare from Amalfi by ferry. A 45 minute trip if you choose to go.

We just got back and spent a week on the Amalfi coast and also took a day trip to Procida. If you only have a day, I would recommend Procida. Its stunning, less crowded, and almost like you’re stepping back in time. Amazing seafood and people. You can walk everywhere and discover quaint streets and shops or take the FREE bus to get around the island. It’s gorgeous!

Ok so still in Rome but wanted to write when it’s fresh
1. Don’t stay on the Vatican side of the river way more going on the other side
Totally reccomend out air bn b only 300ft from trevi fountain

(Before your had incredible porchetta sandwiches at angry pig awesome and filled us up)

comments.comment_text: Can you please post the link to the Airbnb? Thanks!

I actually loved our vrbo near the Vatican! It was a quaint, quiet, true neighborhood and not touristy. We had plenty of cafes and restaurants around us but still could visit the busy tourist areas when we wanted! The city has more to offer than just the well known sites. I’m sure your place is lovely, but there are many perks to venturing outside the tourist spots!
We, too, are booked on the Vatican side at Casa Maria Immacolata. A convent turned to a hotel. Hopefully, we will be happy with the choice.
Good to hear. We will be staying at this place next month.
We loved all of our Air Bnb too. They were great and exceptionally clean

Agree about crossing the river. When I traveled there, the manager of the small inn where we stayed was absolutely wonderful, and the walks in the evening were able to be slow, unhurried and so pleasant.

The manager walked us from the inn to a restaurant a few blocks away and gave us the history of the local buildings as we passed. He was 82 years old, and a delight.

Kept turning to me, and with the high notes and tones of, say a Louis Prima, would say " KIM-ber lee!" at the start of his statements.

I loved staying on the Vatican side because it was more like hanging out with the locals. I stayed at the Hearth Hotel and the staff were super friendly. They helped me find a restaurant with authentic Italian food and a tailor to hem some pants. Also the biggest market in Rome is just a block or so from the hotel. Wandered around for an hour or two! This is just one spot inside the market. Fresh pastries. Excellent coffee. Breads. Pizza. Fish. I bought toothpaste and sunscreen- great prices. Lots of different booths
Yes Vatican side is good and it is also the trastevere side, too crowded on the other side, loved my daily walk across the river.

Trastevere and Vatican areas are perfect. It’s so lovely to be in more authentic and less crowded areas. Trastevere is THE place to eat.
Much too noisy and crowded in the tourist area.
Anywhere near the trevi fountain has to be extremely noisy. It is bit of a walk across the river but we were ok with it. If you are nit a walker choose the otherside.
What site did you find this apartment?
Sasha Ho
Lydia Beverley
We like action and people and gelato and drinks. May not be for everyone but definitely enjoyed by us two adults and two teens

We much preferred staying away from the busy areas during our stay. It felt more local, real, and relaxing. We did not mind walking further as the weather was perfect in the spring (and we have a teen not younger kids).
Jessica Tully Ybarra
We stayed at an air bnb in trastevere neighborhood and loved it! It had a loft and A/c in each room. Top floor with 2 bathrooms. loved being away from major crowds…and we had so many dinner options.
Oh my gosh, I loved staying by the Vatican. Our apartment was spacious and beautiful. Lots of non tourist shops and a quick bus ride anywhere

I actually very much disagree! We stayed a block from the colosseum one night and then moved across the river to Trastevere area (south of Vatican) and hands down everyone in my family (teen boys) loved this area the best! We were still within a 25 minute walk to ALL the historic sites and Trastevere is “the secret sauce” of Rome - best Italian everywhere you eat, beautiful churches (Santa Maria!) and bridges, most romantic settings, and oh my goodness it comes to life at night as the roads become filled with street cafes and there is a summer festival that stretches for miles along the River. This is where the locals go to hang out and eat. Hate to say it, but if you travel to Rome and miss this, you are kinda missing out on much of the culture. Break away from the tourist spots. We stumbled across it and are so glad we did! We stayed at Hotel Trastevere - reasonably priced, great location and very friendly service.
Angry pig in Trastavere is awesome!
We enjoy prati on the Vatican side of the river for folk who like quiet and more residential vs to touristy …59 each his own
I actually really liked being 5 minutes away from the Vatican on the other side of the river. 🤷🏻‍♀️ We were able to sneak in a super early walk without waiting in line to get in.

You want to stay on right side of river, away from Vatican. In same sentence, you complain about terrible noise. We stayed in great place, 4 blocks from Vatican, spacious & quiet with fantastic patio to enjoy in the evening(yes, outside & no noise).
We LOVED staying right by the Trevi !!!
This should not be on FB

I have to respectfully disagree. I lived in Rome for a few months in the Trastevere neighborhood (Vatican side of the Tiber River) and personally think it’s the best way to experience Rome. Quiet on some of the streets and more local feeling, but still an easy walk to many sites or you can hop on the tram which will take you all the way to the Vittoriano. Trastevere has tons of shops and restaurants and is really a great place to stay when you visit Rome.

We loved staying near the Vatican. It was a 2 minute walk, lots of shops and restaurants. everywhere was easy to walk walk transportation was a 2 minute walk. the price was great for our apartment unit on Borgo Pio. Stayed 2x
Prati is a pretty crap neighbourhood for tourists, but Trastevere is gold standard. You can tell too, literally every house is an Airbnb (RIP)

I am also partial to that location/
dining (and they host a flea market).
disagree with #1. We had a wonderful time in April staying in Borgo Pio neighborhood.

text:
I have purchased the Trenitalia Pass, 7 journeys in 15 days.
1 - Is this good for 7 days of travel in a 15 day period? As many trains as I want on each day?
2 - what is included? Do I need a separate ticket for intra city transportation?
3 - How and when do I activate the pass?
4 - How and when do I book the "journeys?" The pass says at the "Trenitalia sales channels."
5 - is this pass also good to get me from Naples to Sorrento with a stop in Pompeii?
I assume this is good for any train on this line, not the private train line.
And is it good for the high speed trains or only ???? trains? and when there at the train stations, is it easy to know which train is which (common sense says if I make it to the right track that I"ll get on the right train). I heard that the tracks change often, so one should stay near the message board until close to time to get to the train. Any tricks to this? How far out should I make my way to the tracks? I have lots of experience riding metros in different places, but no train experience.
Thanks, I think once I do this once everything will be easy, but trying to have all the facts straight before I get there next month.
And I know these questions have been addressed before, but the information is overwhelming. Is there a simple place to read something? A simple guide?

comments.comment_text:
Not sure of the benefit of this “pass” if you still have to book each train before you travel.
To be honest, Ive never heard of this type of pass. Did you purchase through Trenitalia website, if so the T&Cs should have come with the pass, in English???
I have found the website “seat 61” enormously helpful with this stuff. Try there for some answers. 😊
From what I understood from their website - a journey is a single leg of the trip. There’s more info on their website

You bought the pass then look for the information 🤔. I decided against it and used Trainline app to book. It was very easy.

Look at the Board for your train number then the platform will appear about 10 mins before departure. Head straight to the platform and be ready to board when it arrives. All our trains were on time.

I have previously used the train pass. Normally I had to activate it at the station on the day I was using the pass for the first time. It usually required a visit to the station office with my passport. I could then travel on the network as many times as I liked during its period of validity. Generally I booked my train journeys and seats prior to leaving. It’s about 4 years since I last used them. I now think it’s easier to just book trains as I need them.

Trains generally run on time, and they don't wait on you.
Go early and be ready to move. Seats fill up fast.

text:
Just booked our flights to Rome for March 2024. It hasn’t actually hit me yet. I’m excited to finally get to go but nervous at the same time. So much to plan. Been reading a lot on this page of what to do and not to do. Gets a bit overwhelming and confusing. What makes me more nervous is trying to plan our timing so we can figure out where to stay.
This is our itinerary but of course I’m sure will change once I sit down and try to figure out our travel time.
Land in Rome. Because we fly out from Rome, we figure we will stay in Rome the last few days before leaving.
We fly in 3/27 and return home 4/10. We will be in Italy Easter weekend which o read is a busy time.

Day 1-So land in Rome. Same day make our way down to Naples… maybe stay that night in Naples.
Day 2- Naples day to Pompeii evening and stay on Pompei
Day 3-pompei to Amalfi coast.
Days 4-5 stay for 2 days?
Days 6-7 Amalfi coast to Bari. (My ancestors are from Bari) for 2 days
Days 8-9 Bari to countryside of Tuscany.. forgot the name of the city because I don’t have my paper with me.
Days 10-11 .. Tuscany city forgotten name to Florence.. day trip to Pisa
Days 12-14 Florence to Rome.
Leave out day 14
As mentioned, I need to calculate travel time.
Any suggestions on this visit on planning travel or places to stay? I’m open to redoing itinerary. I also need to check to see what there is to see in Naples and Pompei.
My ancestors have a hotel in Naples
We are far from being wealthy. My budget is 2600-3400$ which includes hotel, travel and food expenses.
Thanks in Advance 😁

This is way to much in the time you have. You need 2 nights in each town to give you at least one full day. If one full day is enough (I don't think so) then you could maybe manage this itinerary. I would Base yourself in Sorrento for Pompeii and Amalfi coast portion. No need to stay jn Naples. Skip Pisa, spend more time in Tuscany. Visit San Gimignano and Lucca maybe Siena. Check Rometorio to give you some idea of travel times.
Way too much. I don’t think it will feel like a vacation.
That amount includes airfare?!
Looks fantastic ! Do read up on the new requirements for entry 2024- an ETIAS application might be in effect.
We're getting ready to leave for 2 weeks. We did a tour through cosmos.

Skip Pisa for sure . If you are in Bari and only 10 days focus this time on Rome and south which is Amalfi coast plus Bari. See Matera which is amazing . U will be so tired and you will not experience a lot if the list will be all over the place in 10 days . Italy is stunning everywhere. South Amalfi coast is amazing . Rome as well . Bari probably as well . Matera is close to Bari . You will not regret it . Florence is 3/5 day’s minimum. 2 hours from Venice . Combine those two plus Rome for next trip . Do some Rome this time since u fly there . Explore Amalfi coast and Bari and Matera . Next time Rome Florence Venice 🙂 this is my advice just coming from there and 3 weeks were not enough . We are coming back in September

Instead of staying in Naples or Pompeii,stay in Sorrento, it’s beautiful and much safer! And this I heard from our driver to the train! Pompeii at night is not a good place! You can get to Pompeii from Sorrento, and Amalfi as well, book a tour or take the train right to Pompeii you can take the ferry to Amalfi for the day from Sorrento, we did this and was a great home base to get to Amalfi and Pompeii , have fun putting your trip together, it’s exciting, You will fall in love with Italy, enjoy all the sites and all the food!

I would give the Amalfi coast a miss. If your ancestors come from Bari, would you not be more interested in that area
Day 2…to Pompeii (full day)
Day 3…explore Naples, it’s interesting.
Day 4..to Bari. Lots to do and see in Puglia.
5-7 in Bari
8…Travel to TUSCANY
Day 10-11 to Florence
You need some time in Rome.
We’ve booked ours for May2024 so much good advice from this group…trying to make sure we spend time enjoying all the things Italy had to offer to make everyone love it! We’re excited planning!
Oh wow... Great itinerary. I'm nervous too and trying to figure out the travel logistics there and the timing... its so hard.
Lisa Petricone Cook

Is your budget per person? I think you will spend more.
I would stay in Sorrento & do day trips from there maybe for Pompeii but definitely Amalfi. Otherwise lots of time packing & unpacking. See Florence & Tuscany towns from one central location. Can’t remember where Bari is. Just remember when you calculate travel time - it takes longer than you think it will because part of the time is just figuring everything out whether it’s the trains or other public transport vs if you are driving. Have fun, but SAVE YOUR MONEY bec I’m pretty sure you have under calculated what it will cost.

My two least favourite places on my trip in June was Naples & Pompeii.

My very favourites were basing out of Sorrento, and Lipari, Sicily.

Then flew to Florence and loved horseback riding in Tuscany. Florence itself wasn’t my favourite but glad I went.

I was in Italy this summer. Our group of 6 spent 3 nights each in Rome, Vernazza, Florence, Tuscany, and Venice. Three nights was perfect. Enough time to see the highlights and not too much time spent moving between places.

My best advice…pack light! Take half of the clothes you think you need and do laundry. We washed underwear in our sink using laundry sheets. You do not want big luggage on trains.

Enjoy! Italy is amazing. I’ve now been 3 times.
Fly to Naples, rather than Rome.
U don't want to experience Rome? I like staying in naples and taking the ferry to Sorrento.

So many legit questions. Sounds like you're traveling a lot, but you don't mention if you have tours, etc. planned for each town. If you're going to stay in Pompeii, you should at least see the ancient city. It's pretty amazing. Also, I swear by Tripmasters.com best prices anywhere, and you can customize any aspect of your trip. Also use GRAY LINE TOURS for a perfect experience. But as much as you want to see a much as you can, you need time to rest. I went the last week of March in 2015 and the weather was awesome. A little rainy and chilly sometimes, but only needed a light jacket either way. I'm from New England, btw. Crowds aren't too bad that time of year but if you are going to Rome you should buy skip the line tickets for the larger attractions. Again, Gray Line Tours. Good luck and have a blast!
We went to Sorrento for eight days in 2009. Great location to do Capri, Pompei, Amalfi coast. Stayed at Grand Hotel de la Ville. Sorrento is a lovely small town with very friendly people

I say, you do you! The itinerary may seem busy for some, but if it ticks the boxes for you then go for it.

I have a very busy itinerary, but it's because this was going to be our only trip to Italy in our lifetime. It will be very unlikely for us to return so we wanted to see all of it. While it may seem like we're merely site seeing and not immersing ourselves in the experience, our group just doesn't have that luxury.

We'll be there for 17 days and we've booked all our train tickets, inter city plane tickets and accommodations and we're currently sitting at AUD 1,687.03 for 2 people. This doesn't have our international flights and food yet.

Too many stops for just one 1 consolidate down. They way it looks you’ll be constantly moving and checking into hotels etc!
3 nights minimum in each.
Base out of Sorrento to see Pompeii and Naples and Amalfi. 4-5 nights
Then move to Bari for 3 nights… do day trips from there.
Then head back to see Rome for a few days.
From Bari to Florence is a haul! I’d skip Tuscany this trip and just concentrate on Rome and the South.

Try Cosmos tours.
They are budget friendly. Our tour guide was exceptional.
Other suggestion is for you to get brochures from other tour companies.
They have varied itineraries that you could follow and varied price points.
Globus, Trafalgar, Caravan to name a few.

Your trip is too busy.
I definitely would stay in Rome at least one night in the beginning of your adventure.

How exciting!!
Itinerary looks too busy to me.
Try picking up brochures from various tour companies to use as a guide.
Cosmos is budget friendly. Our guide was incredible and beautiful. Think blonde Sophia Loren!
We went 2 more times on our own.
Italy is so amazing. Savor each day. Have a rewarding time!

I travel to Italy frequently. I'm here now. This is way too ambitious a schedule, even for a seasoned traveler, but you should do whatever works for you. However, I will advise: 1) Most things in Italy come to a screeching halt from Holy Thursday through Easter Monday at a minimum. So do your research carefully.
2) Many ferry lines to/from the Amalfi Coast do not run all year. They are seasonal. Check schedules carefully if you plan to ferry. Also, be aware that most likely, in early April, weather on the Amalfi Coast is usually not "beach weather". What other activities do you have planned on the Coast?
That’s way too much moving around in such a short amount of time
Remember to hire wifi at the airport. That was a great help every time we were there.

We stayed in Bari a few weeks ago. It was our least favorite stop. Suggest staying closer to the beach and Old Bari rather than near the train station.

We took the train to Polignano a Mare. Loved it there! Much more touristy. And likely more expensive to stay than Bari.

We were on Capri for 5 days and loved it. But about double the cost for food and housing. But the yacht and people watching was awesome!
budget is way too low for my opinion. For two plp for two weeks minimum 5000e and even that is tight

Thank you everyone for your comments, suggestion and helpful advice. Short answer to questions asked. It’s just my husband and I. The budget doesn’t include airfare. I saved up x amount of money and that is what was left after airfare. I’m working 2 jobs just to save and have plenty of time to save more. Suggested budget excluding airfare is 5000$. Ok I can make that happen. I have not booked any tours yet, and wasn’t sure if we should.
Knowing they many places may be closed around Easter, I’m wondering if I need to move our dates even after we already purchased the tickets. So seems we need to stay in a hotel for multiple days and not just 1 or 2 nights. May have to cut off a destination.
I’m going to turn off comments for now so I can write down y’all’s(I live in Texas lol) suggestions. Thank you everyone for your helpful tips. 😁

My personal opinion is there are way too many places. Use Naples as a base for Amalfi coast and Pompeii. Bonus is hopefully your family cuts you a break on hotel. Also, Amalfi coast is super expensive so by day tripping, you save money.
Too many locations. Pick three. Assume every time you travel to a new place, it’s a full day basically gone.

Any chance you can change your flights without significant cost?
In to Rome, out of Naples or vice versus would save you considerable time and cost.
If not. Consider staying in sorrento as base. Easy train and too many cities/move for two week trip

Work out the journey time for each leg. It takes more time than you expect. I traveled in 4 hour train journeys and allowed a day for it because by the time you check out, get to station in time, travel to destination, get to accommodation, check in, basically it takes the day. My second day I did the sights. 3rd day I chilled and wandered around. Next day traveled. That's how I planed. Then I spent a week in Bari 😁
Sue Shurow Deebel

Go from Rome directly to Sorrento by train , from Sorrento easy train to Pompeii and Ferries to Amalfi coast and Capri.
Drive to Matera one night , continue to Puglia and cities you want to visit. Easter events can be fun to see , some crazy...
All day long drive to Florence , visit Tuscany etc.
Drive to Rome , drop off car and visit Rome and its wonderful sights.
Train back to Airport.
Have a great time !

Does stated budget include airfare (hopefully not)? Are you renting a car or taking trains? Looks like you might have one night free lodging in Naples? Otherwise, are you planning on hotels or Air B & B's? That's a lot of bopping around. You will feel rushed and by the fifth location you're going to be tired of checking in and out of lodging, packing and unpacking, etc.
We are going to same time!!! We are staying in Sorrento for 3 nights, Rome 3 nights , Tuscany 3 nights and Venice 3 nights! I'm learning a lot from this group also.

We are planning to go to Rome, Florence and the Tuscan countryside in March as well, but only 9 days. You might have a bit too much planned? Lots of travel. You might want to eliminate a couple of stops
Way to many places, too much time spent moving from town to town. I would base in 3 towns. Get a map and look at your plans. Then look on Rome2Rio to find travel time.

Day 1-land in Rome and stay 3 nights. Next: Florence, Capitol of Tuscany, 3 nights, possibly a day trip to Pisa, but not much time, explore Florence.
Train to Naples for 2 nights with a morning trip to Pompeii.
on your way to the Amalfi Coast
Amalfi Coast for 2 days
2 days in Bari and on the 13th head for a final night in Rome.
Leave out of Rome on day 14. Another option would be to Not go to the Amalfi Coast this trip, it's a lot of traveling around with many hours of it, wasting time, checking in, checking out, etc. Add those days to be with family in Napoli or explore the Bari area. Amalfi Coast is expensive.
Including airfare?

Budget seems a bit tight. Depending on any shopping and higher end restaurants.
We figure minimum $200 per day per person. Just as a guideline.
So 2 people for 14 days is $5600. I know that is on the high end but would be prepared to spend $4-5,000 total.
Also agree too many locations. You won’t have any breathing room. Focus on 3 major cities. I personally would do Lake Como not Amalfi.
Rome, Lake Como and Tuscany/
Florence.
The ap rometorio is good for planning travel time.

When “staying 2 days”, the actual time you will be spending is one full day. You need to factor in your moving/
traveling time on departure/
arrival in each town. You will be busy packing and unpacking almost every other day. You’ll lose so much precious time. I can see that you want to cover as many places as you can, but it’s too many places that you won’t be able to enjoy each town. Have a base somewhere and do day trips from there.
About Bari. You mentioned that your ancestors are from Bari. Don’t you want to stay there more than “2 days”? (Because I would love to spend more time with family if I were you)
You technically have 13 days to spend. I would recommend that you narrow down to 3 locations and take day trips from each base. For example, if you can stay at your ancestors’ hotel at reasonable rates, Napoli is a great base to visit Pompeii by train and Amalfi coast by ferry. For Toscana, have a base in Firenze. Both trains and buses are well connected.

I picked itinerary and booked rooms then started planning transportation.
Discovered that trans can take a lot of time. And the train fares add up. If you have long travel between destinations, you really only have 1 full day there on a 2 night stay. BTW, we are staying 2 nights in Pompei at a small hotel, only 50 euro per night includes breakfast. We were going to stay in Salerno because its less than half the price of Positano. From Salerno you can take the fe or bus to check out Almafi, Positano, etc. But I already had an apartment on the beach in Nerano Cantone (about 150 per night) for 2 nights, and we can take a local big tour boat for a brief tour of Almafi & Positano (50 euro) so gave up Salerno (added its days to Nerano, Spello & Florence). From Nerano to Spello will take us 8 hours, 1 bus, 4 trains. We are in Italy for 22 nights. IMO your Itinerary is too expansive.

I would fly into Rome and take the train directly to Naples. Hotels in Rome will be very expensive because of Easter. As will the Amalfi Coast where many Italians go for Easter Holidays. Naples will be budget friendly. Then use Naples as your base you can take the train to Pompeii and ferry to the Coast. Then take the train from Naples to Bari. Stay in this region because it will be cost effective ( Tuscany is expensive and the countryside is very similar) you will get a unique and really authentic experience. Then take the train to Rome spend a few days then fly home. The itinerary you have planned will cost you 4-5,000. Staying in Puglia will be way less expensive.
Why not Rome, Naples, Bari, then go North for Tuscany and Amalfi? I haven’t been there yet but just looking at the map, that would make the most of your time. Wishing you a fabulous trip!

Have the best time ever! Recently returned from a week tour in Italy through Greca travel (carrani tours/grey line) a week in Greece tour, then a week on our own in Italy. I remembered travelling with my mom when she was older (as I am now) and WHEN I’m back in Italy (I loved it SO much❤️🇮🇹❤️…) I will spend more time in one place….definite
ly planning 3-4 days in Florence, 4 days in Rome, 3 days in Tuscany region, and 3 days in Venice. We returned from Greece to Naples, took the bus to Sorrento, stayed one night (I wish it had been longer) then took the boat back to Naples, got to our b&b, hit Pompeii, and the next morning were up at 4am for our flight to Genoa. (I would definitely like to explore Naples for a few days also….In Genoa we took the train to La Spezia where we were staying….then visited two of the 5 Cinque Terre villages….then next day train back to Rome for two days. I had gotten heat stroke in Pompeii, so that killed the end of our adventures in Cinque Terra and Rome sadly….we had planned a night in between CT to go back to Florence but went right to Rome instead. I was just happy to be able to catch my flight home without any sickness issues…..defini
tely pack Imodium and pepto bismol…if needed it will be easier than searching when not feeling well…anyway now from experience….I definitely will not spend only one night in any place ever again….it’s just too much of a pain to pack up and move on a daily basis…at least for me. Definitely prebook hotels if possible, luckily the person I travelled with had some time share options and that worked out well budget wise, but last minute hotels in July would have been crazy expensive. Have an amazing time!!! ❤️🇮🇹👌🏻👌🏻👌🏻
Be aware that Italy is a catholic country and there may be a lot closed for this holiday.

text:
This is an odd question,

everytime I travel I like to bring think for the less fortunate. Most of the time kid. Is there notable poverty in rome? París? Palma de mayorca? La Spezia? Barcelona? Madrid? Marseille? Genoa?naples?

comments.comment_text: Yes, of course, there are poor, especially with all the refugees. You'll see them on the streets if not the camps but you won't see camps unless you go there. Buy them something to eat if you want to do something, Stuff, they don't need.
Yes, there will be refugees and homeless, some beggars. I agree, buy some extra fruits and foods if you'd like. You'll also be helping the small businesses with stalls.
Yes...there are homeless, impoverished and unwell people in every town and city. I have just finished 5 months travel in 16 countries and sad to see.
This is such a patronising post...
there are poor people everywhere - and there are some that just pretend to extract money from tourists, be careful!

You better do some research and find a trustworthy organisation in the area you are visiting, and give them some money, if you want to help who really needs. Just giving out money to the first ill-looking beggar you find on the street is likely to foster organised crime

So, as lovely as this thought is. And I always encourage people to follow their heart but whether you are at home or travelling, it is almost (barring a failing corrupt government) always better to give to an organization that helps those in need. For example I work in a food pantry in the US. A box of cereal from the grocery store donated to one person helps one person for a few days. A donation of the cost of that cereal can help several people for a week. Organizations can purchase bulk, at discounted prices. Your dollars go further. You help way more people. Systems and organizations can have significant impact as they know the needs of their community, often very well. In the world of poverty...cash is king, and in short supply most places. Just something to consider.

Check out the organization Not Just Tourists. They have several locations and help tourists take suitcases full of unused medical supplies to countries and locations that need them. They supply suitcases and supplies, you just check and connect.

text:
Starting to plan a 2024 visit to Italy and have some questions....
1. Could be my only trip to Italy, what are the places and spaces I shouldn't miss?
2. April or September?
3. Book a tour or go at it and plan on my own?
4. Should I try to squeeze in a neighboring area, such as Spain for example?
5. How long is the ideal trip?
Appreciate any of your advice and lived experiences.

comments.comment_text: How long are you going for?

Either April or September. Have 2 to 3 weeks and base in 2 or 3 cities and do day trips from there. I would do base in Florence and Rome or Venice. Side trip to Pompei from Rome. If 3 weeks do also Amalfi Coast based in Sorrento or Lake Como area based in Varenna.

What are you into. Checking iconic sights off your bucket list, architecture, art, food people watching, figuring out how other folks solve life's issues, getting to know a country, meeting fellow travelers, meeting folks from the country you are visiting or/and learning a new language, experiencing la vita dolce, or not sure why. Answer those questions and the collective we can help you plan your trip.

We went in 2. April for 5. 14 full days plus travel (so 16 total), to 1. Rome, Venice, Lake Como, and Cinque Terre. 3. We planned and booked everything on our own. It was amazing! Would change nothing. Our budget was $14,000 for 4 people and we traveled with 2 others who shared Airbnb’s with us.

3 / 4 weeks best
Land in Milan .. Fly out of Rome
Rent a car and don't pre-book anything.
Spend your nights outside of tourist traps will save you a ton of money.
Milan to Switzerland across to Lake Como to Venice, through Tuscany to Pisa to Florence.
Shoot down the Almafi Coast. Across to Alberobello, back to Nsples up to Rome for few days before departure.
It is plenty of time and if you do not pre-book you can come and go as you please.

We were in Italy in late Sept of 2017. Flew into Rome from the US. We are not into busy cities. Rented a car in Rome and spent 6 days in Tuscany and then drove to the Amalfi Coast and spent 6 days in Vietri Sul Mar. after realizing not smart to drive around there (except for Ravello) we parked the car and ferried everywhere. Then drove back to Rome and flew home. It was magical! Driving is doable but ill advised and parking was a nightmare. Preferred the smaller towns of Praiano, Māori, and Minori. Fabulous!

You do not need to book tours. Stay in a small town on the coast and ferry everywhere. It’s easy (and cheaper). In Tuscany we drove everywhere we wanted to go and it was easy (parking can be an issue).

Go for three weeks. Don’t squeeze in another country. I’d go April for the spring flowers.
Venice and Rome would be my ‘essential’ items. I’m not into the coastal towns, but the lakes are amazing.

What is your interest(s) in Italia? Why do you want to visit there? Ask yourself these questions and start building your only trip to Italia. Have a copy of Rick Steves Italy guidebook. He covers the most popular cities throughout Italia. It’s a survival guide, too. Check his book and find your potential locations. His book also recommends how much time/days you should spend/stay in each town

Not sure your preferences on towns…don’t know your interests. I would say at least a few days in rome as it’s a good hub to fly into and although a big city it is a city unlike others. We were there and amalfi coast end of June and beginning of July. I wasn’t sure I would ever get back either so I planned based on my interests and my kids. I planned it all myself so that we could hit all the places/
activities I knew we would personally love. It was a lot of work but worth it and made it more fun…I’m my opinion

If you want to incorporate another country, spend some days in Genoa. You can take the train from there to Monaco and Nice and spend the night or a few days. We love Genoa and are going back in 2024 for 9 days there.
First time do a tour. Check out globus/cosmos.

How long is the "ideal" trip? The longer the better. 3 months would be perfect, and I saw your photo, you are young, and this will not be your 1st and only trip!! Guarantee it! 1st we all need more details, Sept / Oct better time than April. Since you have a little over a year, you have plenty of time to write out a couple plans based on the number of days, read, learn, ask for opinions, but ultimately make your own decisions and plans. Sounds like you need to start figuring it out 1st, so basically you have an idea of what the different areas and cities are about. What do you like to do? Hike? Nature? Explore the famous sites? Museums, tours, cooking classes.... a lot to start doing your homework 1st.

How much time can you stay and in your budget? A month would be really super. April will be less crowded than Sept and prob better pricing. September is more of a shoulder month and still more “ high season.”
Maybe consider 3-4 different bases for your stay.
Following!

Our first trip was a month and it wasn’t long enough so now we are going back for 3 months. If you have 3-4 weeks, I would do the Amalie coast with Ciro la Motta, Taxi Mister Cab Driver-Naples & Amalfi coast-over 3-4 days. Then go up to Rome for a week, Florence for a week, then possibly Venice. You can always take day trip out of Florence. Good luck and most of all enjoy

Places you shouldn't miss depend on what you're looking for: countryside, metropolis, mountains, etc. Anyway I'd say Rome, Venice and Palermo are worth a visit at least once in a lifetime. September is less busy but still warm. Plan on your own if you're good at researching. Italy is already a handful, l wouldn't add any other country. The ideal vacation is as long as possible: pack smart, dress in layers, comfy wash n wear clothes, dressy is not required.
Anybody driven in the Dolomites towards end of May, if so, how was the weather generally and were restaurants, activities, cable car etc open

Well Italy is a huge country, so first of all decide you want to see historical sites like Roma, Florence..or seaside places. I would recomend definately to see Venice once in a lifetime. What time April or september? As the end if April can be arround +20 (or not) and the begining of September can be quite warm or hot, but the sea water still can be warm enough to swim 😉 how much time you have? You use public transport or a car? As driving to Spain can take time ;)

Make life easier! Go on a tour!! Pack your bags and enjoy. They do all the work, you just soak it all in. And you get some free time. I took two different tour with Collette Tours - awesome, worth it!
Don’t worry once you go once it is love at first sight. You will go back . It calls you 🇮🇹🇮🇹

St Peter’s Basilica! We went on Sunday last month. They have Mass every hour and since the museums are closed on Sunday, that is the best day to visit St Peter’s. We were glad we went then. Mass was beautiful and the crowd was a quarter of the size as the next day.
